meanings.definition: To go to or live in the country
meanings.sent1: During the summer, my family likes to rusticate in our cozy cabin by the lake.
meanings.sent2: Many people rusticate in rural areas to enjoy the peace and quiet away from the city.
meanings.sent3: The city dweller decided to rusticate in the countryside but got lost in the vast fields.
meanings.sent4: The idea of rustication in a remote village seemed like a dream come true for the tired traveler.
meanings.sent5: She longed to rusticate in the serene countryside, surrounded by nature's beauty.

meanings.definition: To give a rustic appearance to
meanings.sent1: The artist used special techniques to rusticate the wooden furniture, giving it an antique look.
meanings.sent2: The old barn was rusticated with weathered wood and vintage decorations for the wedding.
meanings.sent3: The interior designer decided to rusticate the modern apartment, adding wooden beams and earthy tones.
meanings.sent4: The quaint cottage was rusticated with stone walls and a thatched roof, blending perfectly with the landscape.
meanings.sent5: The garden was rusticated with wildflowers and wooden benches, creating a charming rustic atmosphere.

meanings.definition: To suspend from school or college for disciplinary reasons
meanings.sent1: The principal had to rusticate the troublemaker for a week due to repeated misbehavior.
meanings.sent2: The university decided to rusticate the student who was caught cheating on the exam.
meanings.sent3: The teacher threatened to rusticate the student if he didn't stop disrupting the class.
meanings.sent4: The strict school rules allowed the administration to rusticate students who violated the code of conduct.
meanings.sent5: The dean had no choice but to rusticate the student for breaking the school's zero-tolerance policy.
